I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to India for the Assam Urban Infrastructure Investment 
Program. 
 
2.  The proposed MFF will finance a portion of the urban infrastructure initiatives of the 
Government of Assam for the cities of Guwahati and Dibrugarh.1 It will improve the urban 
services in these cities by improving water supply, sanitation, solid waste management (SWM), 
drainage infrastructure, and urban transport to the standards set by the State.2  
 
II.  THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Assam is the gateway for developing India’s northeast because of its strategic position 
and relatively large population of 31.17 million.3 An examination of urban service delivery in the 
13 largest towns of Assam found most performance indicators below the national average, as 
shown in Table 1.

4.  Currently, only 30% of the 1.0 million residents of Guwahati city, the capital of Assam, 
have piped water,4 the rest depending on wells5 and water vendors who charge high rates. The 
city is divided into four water supply zones. Water supply projects in the north and south-central

zones are financed by the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA). In south Guwahati, 
water supply in the west zone is financed under the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal 
Mission  (JNNURM).  The  proposed  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  assistance  is  for  the 
southeast zone.6 Guwahati also needs a sewerage treatment plant and network to treat the 
incremental  wastewater  that  will  be  generated  by  the  water  supply  subprojects.  Rapid 
urbanization combined with increased vehicular traffic, a deteriorating road network, poor traffic 
management, and the lack of an efficient, reliable, and safe public transport system cause air 
pollution  and  increased  road  accidents,  impeding  Guwahati’s  economic  development.  The 
Guwahati Development Department (GDD) of the Government of Assam is developing plans for 
a more sustainable and reliable mass transport system. In Dibrugarh, inadequate SWM and the 
indiscriminate dumping of waste leave the drainage system severely polluted, choked, and 
prone to severe local flooding during the rainy season. 
 
5.  Road map for achieving service level targets and urban transport. ADB helped the 
Government of Assam to formulate a sector assessment to serve as a road map for 2011–2021 
toward meeting national and state targets for water supply, sewerage, and SWM in Guwahati 
and Dibrugarh and urban transport in Guwahati.7 The key findings are as follows: 
(i)  The investment for water supply, sewerage, and SWM infrastructure is estimated 
to cost Rs33 billion by 2021 and incur annual operation and maintenance (O&M) 
costs of Rs1.6 billion upon completion. 
(ii)  To  create  a  sustainable  environment  for  investment,  it  is  necessary 8  for  
Guwahati and Dibrugarh urban local bodies (ULBs)9 to (a) formulate and adopt 
policies on user charges and subsidies, (b) establish separate accounts for each 
urban  service  operation,  and  (c)  install  automated  billing  systems  for  user 
charges. 
(iii)  Interventions should support the 2009 master plan for Guwahati, which aims to 
(a)  conserve  the  natural  environment;  (b)  develop  an  integrated,  multimodal 
transport system with three mass transit lines; and (c) develop physical and 
social infrastructure for education, health care, and cultural enrichment as well as 
for water supply and SWM. 
(iv)  The  investment  in  construction  management,  systemic  improvements  in 
operations, and capacity building will require Rs636 million.10 
 
6.  Long-term policy support. Two program loans, for subprogram 111 and subprogram 
2,12 were provided by ADB to help the Government of Assam improve revenue administration 
and strengthen expenditure and debt management. The expected benefits are more resources 
available for social and economic infrastructure and budget resources more efficiently allocated 
toward the outcomes sought. The outcome of the investment program is improved municipal

7.  Strategic  context  for  ADB  and  urban  service  delivery.  The  country  partnership 
strategy13 and ADB’s assistance program for 2007–2012 support the Government of India’s 
efforts to address binding constraints on the plan through four strategic pillars.14 The country 
partnership  strategy  stresses  continuing  ADB’s  assistance  to  infrastructure  development, 
including urban infrastructure. The country operations business plan for India, 2011–201315 
allocates an MFF of up to $200 million for the Assam Urban Infrastructure Investment Program 
for processing in 2011. 
 
8.  India and urban service delivery. India’s plan has set out 27 national targets, both 
economic and social, including (i) clean drinking water available to all by 2009, ensuring that 
there is no slippage by the end of the plan, and (ii) treating all urban wastewater by 2011–2012 
to reduce river pollution. The plan calls for public investment to meet infrastructure requirements 
where private participation is less likely. 
 
9.  Policy framework and ongoing initiatives. The Government of India has been the 
most prominent financier in Assam through various national schemes. The centrally sponsored 
JNNURM, the Urban Infrastructure Development Scheme for Small and Medium Towns, and 
other  national  and  state  budgetary  allocations  are  available  but  inadequate  to  meet  the 
complete  investment  requirement.  The  government  has  undertaken  several  initiatives  for 
economic  development  in  the  northeast  with  ADB  assistance.  During  the  2010  country 
programming mission, Assam was identified as the recipient of the proposed ADB assistance. 
 
10.  Investment program for urban infrastructure in Guwahati and Dibrugarh, including 
external assistance. Major investments in urban infrastructure were identified in the 2006 city 
development plan, aiming to attract funding from the JNNURM. The plan envisions investments 
in  Guwahati  and  Dibrugarh  of  $860.49  million,  toward  which  financing  secured  from  the 
JNNURM is $143.58 million and JICA $318.00 million, leaving a funding gap of $398.91 million. 
ADB financing of $200.00 million was requested. The Government of Assam is seeking an 
additional $120.00 million from JICA for wastewater treatment and networks in Guwahati. The 
balance of $78.91 million will be financed by the Government of Assam. The urban services 
investment program in Guwahati of $575.36 million, supported by ADB, JICA, and JNNURM, 
covers 44% of the total investment requirement of $1.30 billion for the 13 largest cities in 
Assam. Similarly, the investment program for urban transport in Guwahati of $205.12 million 
covers 20% of the total urban transport investment requirement of $1.00 billion for the 13 largest 
cities. 
 
11.  The  MFF  modality  was  selected  to  allow  phased  implementation  and  funding  of 
individual projects when they are ready, subject to eligibility and readiness of subprojects which 
are 16 included in the investment program.17 The requirements for an MFF are in place. The 
Government of Assam has prepared a sector strategy supported by an investment plan over the 
next ten years.18

12.  Policy dialogue. Policy dialogue with the Government of Assam will develop a strategic 
and integrated approach to sustainably improving the urban environment and quality of life. 
First, meters installed for all consumers in the service areas will support the transition from the 
current  flat  rates  to  volumetric  rates  for  water  supply,  enhancing  cost  recovery,  demand 
management, and water conservation.19 Second, institutional reforms will improve the efficiency 
and strengthen the capacity of the Guwahati Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board 
(GMWSSB), which will be an autonomous entity responsible for managing and operating all 
water supply and sanitation facilities in Guwahati, including the collection of tariffs, with effect 
from 2015.20 Third, institutional reform and organizational development in urban transport will 
bring into being an authority to plan, manage, and coordinate all transportation in the city. 
Further, policy and institutional reforms under the JNNURM in Guwahati complements the policy 
dialogue under the investment program (footnote 8). Key lessons from past ADB water supply 
projects21 have been considered in the design of the investment program, including the need to 
increase water use efficiency and focus on cost recovery and institutional matters. Further, the 
GDD  will  prepare  a  detailed  road  map  for  revising  tariffs,  setting  out  milestones  toward 
introducing revised water tariffs to meet full O&M costs, and establishing sewerage fees and 
solid waste management user charges in Guwahati and Dibrugarh by 2018. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The impact of the investment program will be an improved access to water supply, 
sanitation, and urban infrastructure facilities by the urban population in Guwahati and Dibrugarh. 
The expected outcome will be improved and sustainable water supply, sanitation, and urban 
transport system in Guwahati and Dibrugarh. The investment program will help India achieve 
the Millennium Development Goals on environment sustainability and increased access to safe 
drinking water and basic sanitation. An integrated and holistic approach is being designed under 
which six outputs will be delivered. The two tranches under the MFF will be implemented in 6 
years from 2012 to 2017.22 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
14.  Output  1:  Improved  water  supply  infrastructure  in  Guwahati.  Investments  will 
provide high-quality, 24-hour-a-day water supply to 350,000 residents in the southeastern zone 
of Guwahati by 2018.23 This includes constructing a water intake and water diversion structures, 
water  treatment  facility,  water  transmission  system  and  service  reservoirs,  laying  all-new 
distribution pipes, and limiting nonrevenue water to less than 15%, which is below the Ministry 
of Urban Development benchmark of 20%. 
 
15.  Output 2: Improved sewerage infrastructure in Guwahati. Investments will address 
100% of the incremental wastewater generated by the ADB-funded water supply subproject. It

16.  Output 3: Improved solid waste management infrastructure in Dibrugarh. SWM 
service  coverage  in  Dibrugarh  will  be  increased  to  more  than  80%  with  in-house  waste 
collection, segregation, recycling and improved solid waste collection, transportation, treatment, 
and disposal. 
 
17.  Output 4: Improved drainage in Dibrugarh. Flow in the existing Dibrugarh protection 
drain will be improved by removing accumulated silt and waste, drain enlargement, and the 
widening and reconstruction of all the road and flood relief culverts, bridges and sluice gates 
which will significantly reduce flooding in the city. 
 
18.  Output 5: Improved urban transport infrastructure in Guwahati. One BRT corridor of 
10.5  kilometers  will  be  developed  under  the  MFF.  The  expected  benefit  of  the  BRT  is 
significantly  shortened  travel  times  and  improved  public  transport  safety  and  reliability, 
encouraging a progressive modal shift from private cars to public transport, thereby reducing air 
pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. 
 
19.  Output  6:  Facility  management  and  implementation  support,  community 
awareness,  and  program  performance  monitoring. This component will provide funding 
support for costs associated with MFF management and implementation, including equipment, 
logistics, and the services of consultants to assist the program management unit (PMU) in 
carrying out detailed design, construction supervision, and related training and capacity building. 
The  detailed  design  will  consider  reliable,  energy-efficient  technology  that  cuts  costs. 
Community outreach and program performance monitoring will be carried out by an experienced 
and  capable  nongovernment  organization  (NGO)  or  consulting  firm.  A  capacity  building 
technical  assistance  for  the  Assam  Urban  Infrastructure  Investment  Program  has  been 
approved under the ongoing cluster technical assistance.24 The main outputs are (i) blueprint 
organizational structure for GMWSSB as a ring-fenced and sustainable autonomous entity; (ii) 
central knowledge center in the state, from which sector-related information and best practices 
in urban municipal services can be sourced and where training can be provided to ULB staff; (iii) 
toolkit to be used to implement public–private partnership projects in urban services; and (iv) 
management information system for use by ULB managers and state government officials.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
26.  All physical components will be designed to withstand earthquakes. Mitigation will be 
designed into land development, transmission and distribution pipelines, building foundations 
and structures, road pavements, and other urban infrastructure. Geological and geotechnical 
analysis during detailed design will ensure that pipelines and road alignments follow feasible 
routes. Energy-efficient technical options to reduce operating costs will be pursued. Most water-
supply and wastewater-treatment systems will be gravity fed, to minimize O&M costs. The storm 
water drainage subproject in Dibrugarh will increase channel flow capacity and reduce flood 
risk. Further, the procurement of new equipment and construction of new sanitary landfill will 
improve solid waste management, making Dibrugarh cleaner and putting it in compliance with 
the  Municipal  Solid  Waste  (Management  &  Handling)  Rules,  2000.  Rigorous  and  detailed 
analysis of technical options and design optimization have avoided significant resettlement 
impacts from the Guwahati water treatment plant and the SWM landfill in Dibrugarh. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
27.  The economic analysis assessed the economic rationale for government intervention,  
which  is  justified  as  the  investment  program  supports  basic  public  services.27 To  achieve 
economy and efficiency in implementation, each PFR will assess demand, willingness-to-pay, 
and least-cost designs, as well as ensure economic internal rates of return higher than the 
economic opportunity cost of capital, as specified in the subproject selection criteria of the FFA. 
Under project 1, the economic internal rate of return is 16% for the Guwahati water supply 
subproject,  19.7%  for  the  Dibrugarh  drainage  improvement  subproject,  and  14.4%  for  the 
Dibrugarh solid waste management subproject. Financial internal rates of return and net present 
value  have  been  computed  for  the  revenue-generating  water  supply  and  solid  waste 
management subproject at May 2011 prices. The financial internal rate of return is 4.7% for the 
Guwahati  water  supply  subproject  and  7.4%  for  the  Dibrugarh  solid  waste  management 
subproject, both above the weighted average cost of capital of 3.21%. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
28.  The financial management capacity of the GDD and the project implementing units 
(PIUs) has been assessed as adequate.28 The PMU staff will need additional technical staff and 
training on ADB procurement and disbursement procedures. The following steps will or have 
been undertaken: 
(i)  Each tranche under the MFF will be processed as a project loan. Project 1 has 
only  three  investment  subprojects  to  gradually  build  capacity  for  contract 
management and construction supervision. 
(ii)  ADB completed detailed training in May and June 2011 for the staff of the PMU.29 
 
29.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the governments of India and Assam, and the GDD. Specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the facility administration manual.30 
                                                
27 Economic analysis of the investment program was carried out in accordance with D. Dole. 2005. Assessing Aid for 
a Sector Development Plan: Economic Analysis of a Sector Loan. ERD Technical Note. No. 14. Manila: ADB. 
28 The GDD, the executing agency for the investment program, has strong capacity and experience in implementing 
ADB program loans. 
29 The India Resident Mission conducted two workshops for project officials in Guwahati in May and June 2011 on 
ADB requirements regarding safeguards, procurement, disbursement, financial management, and governance.

9 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
30.  The investment program supports Millennium Development Goal 7, on environmental 
sustainability. Pro-poor interventions in project 1 include (i) a baseline survey to identify poor 
and vulnerable households for service delivery, (ii) a community awareness program to educate 
and  inform  the  poor  of  investment  program  benefits,  (iii)  a  behavioral  change  program to 
improve personal sanitation and hygiene, and (iv) a community-based primary waste collection 
system in Dibrugarh. As tranche 1 is classified as effective gender mainstreaming, a gender 
action plan and consultation and participation strategy were prepared to ensure widespread and 
meaningful participation with an emphasis on the poor and women.31 The gender action plan 
and consultation and participation strategy will be implemented with the assistance of an NGO 
and quarterly monitoring and reporting of progress. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
31.  Environmental  safeguards.  Tranche  1  is  classified  category  B  for  environment. 
Tranche 2 is expected to be classified category B (to be confirmed during implementation). 
Three initial environmental examinations were prepared in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009) and government laws. Environmental benefits include (i) more and 
better drinking water and reduced waterborne disease in Guwahati, (ii) reduced contamination 
of soil and waterways and emissions of harmful gases from improved solid waste management 
in Dibrugargh, and (iii) reduced waterborne disease and flooding from improved drainage in 
Dibrugargh. Consultant support will ensure that the PMU and the PIUs have adequate capacity 
to  manage  environmental  impacts.  The  subprojects  are  likely  to  cause  minor-to-moderate 
environmental  disruption  during  construction.  The  GDD  will  be  fully  responsible  for 
implementing the mitigating measures specified in the initial environmental examinations, which, 
along  with  environmental  management  plans,  will  be  updated  during  detailed  design  and 
incorporated  into  bidding  and  contract  documents.  Environmental  reporting to  ADB  will  be 
semiannual. An environmental assessment and review framework was prepared to guide the 
preparation of subprojects in tranche 2.32 
 
32.  Social safeguards. Tranche 1 is classified category B for involuntary resettlement and 
category  C  for  indigenous  peoples.  Tranche  2  is  potentially  category  A  for  involuntary 
resettlement  and  indicatively  category  C  for  indigenous  peoples  (to  be  confirmed  during 
implementation). For tranche 1 subprojects, three draft resettlement plans were prepared in 
consultation with affected people, in accordance with the ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement, 
and  disclosed.  Tranche  1  requires  minor  land  acquisition  with  no  significant  resettlement 
impacts anticipated. The resettlement plans will be implemented by the PIUs and monitored by 
the PMU. Adequate international and national consultancy inputs will be provided by the design 
and supervision consultant, project management consultant, and NGO and through the loan and 
TA to support the resettlement plan, implementation, and monitoring. Capacity will be built for 
managing  the  resettlement  impacts  and  social  risks  of  the  investment  program,  including 
potential impacts arising from the BRT component in tranche 2. As these subprojects are urban, 
no impact on indigenous people is expected. A resettlement framework and indigenous peoples 
planning framework were prepared to guide the preparation of subprojects in tranche 2.33 
                                                                                                                                                       
30 The  Financial  Management  Assessment  for  the  GDD,  implementing  agency,  and  PIUs  are  in  the  Facility 
Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
31 Gender Action Plan, and Consultation and Participation Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in 
Appendix 2). 
32 Environmental Assessment and Review Framework (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
33 Resettlement  Framework,  and  Indigenous  Peoples  Planning  Framework  (accessible  from  the  list  of  linked 
documents in Appendix 2).

10 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
33.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 5. The benefits of the 
investment program are expected to outweigh the potential costs from risks and are detailed in 
the risk assessment and management plan.34 
 
Table 5: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Inadequate urban institutions  The successful implementation of the Asian Development Bank’s 
and limited municipal finances  program loans will strengthen revenue administration, expenditure 
control, and debt management, creating fiscal latitude for the 
Government of Assam and the implementation of reforms introduced by 
the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission. 
Unsustainability of projects  Design-build-operate contracts include operation for 3 years, metering 
of all consumers, and moving from flat to volumetric tariffs, which will 
contribute to project sustainability. 
No bidder interested in design- The executing and implementing agencies will  organize prebid 
build-operate contracts  meetings to clear up the doubts and worries of potential contractors. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
34.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the investment program shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the facility administration manual and loan documents. 
 
35.  The governments of India and Assam have given ADB certain undertakings for the MFF, 
which are set forth in the FFA. Specific covenants agreed by the governments with respect to 
individual tranches under the MFF are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement for 
the respective tranches. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the provision of loans under the multitranche financing facility in an aggregate principal 
amount not exceeding $200,000,000 to India for the Assam Urban Infrastructure Investment 
Program, from ADB's ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance 
with ADB's London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, and such other terms 
and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the framework financing 
agreement presented to the Board. 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
